I've only skimmed the article, but it sounded like they were much more interested in the theoretical brain models they built and the relevation that "lower IQ people think less about decisions", than actually having the title make sense.
Because, as you said, yes, stupid people will come to a conclusion quicker. Doesn't mean they're right and the title even implying that is already a little clickbaity. Also absolutely obvious, of course.
A toddler is also gonna finish a painting faster than an adult artist. Doesn't mean the multi-colored handprint, smeared across the canvas is the same as the Mona Lisa.

name: theArtOfProgramming
comment:
Most interesting to me is the primary goal of this work, that they developed a learning algorithm to identify on the human brain structures and then were able to make inferences based on which structures were faster/better at which problems. That’s super cool.
Full Abstract
To better understand how network structure shapes intelligent behavior, we developed a learning algorithm that we used to build personalized brain network models for 650 Human Connectome Project participants. We found that participants with higher intelligence scores took more time to solve difficult problems, and that slower solvers had higher average functional connectivity. With simulations we identified a mechanistic link between functional connectivity, intelligence, processing speed and brain synchrony for trading accuracy with speed in dependence of excitation-inhibition balance. Reduced synchrony led decision-making circuits to quickly jump to conclusions, while higher synchrony allowed for better integration of evidence and more robust working memory. Strict tests were applied to ensure reproducibility and generality of the obtained results. Here, we identify links between brain structure and function that enable to learn connectome topology from noninvasive recordings and map it to inter-individual differences in behavior, suggesting broad utility for research and clinical applications.

name: Necessary-Feature576
comment: Smart people don't jump to conclusions so that they can move on to the next thing. They know that the problem will creep back up if the root of the issue wasnt addressed

name: giuliomagnifico
comment:
Paper
Learning how network structure shapes decision-making for bio-inspired computing
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-023-38626-y
Resting-state functional MRI scans showed that slower solvers had higher average functional connectivity, or temporal synchrony, between their brain regions. In personalized brain simulations of the 650 participants, the researchers could determine that brains with reduced functional connectivity literally “jump to conclusions” when making decisions, rather than waiting until upstream brain regions could complete the processing steps needed to solve the problem.

name: Nickwharton92
comment:
After reviewing the research article and going through the comments in the Reddit thread, I noticed that one aspect that hasn't been brought up yet is the potential application of these findings in the field of artificial intelligence (AI). In the research, Professor Petra Ritter and her team effectively created "brain avatars" that replicated the decision-making patterns and intellectual performance of their biological counterparts1.
A key take-away from this study is that higher synchronization, or the formation of functional networks in the brain, affects the properties of working memory and thus the ability to endure prolonged periods without a decision. This gathering of evidence for a particular solution may sometimes take longer, but it leads to better results1.
This understanding of the role of synchronization in decision-making and problem-solving could have implications for the development of AI. By mimicking the "slow thinking" approach of intelligent human brains, we could potentially develop AI systems that are better at problem-solving and decision-making, even if they take a bit longer to arrive at a decision. Such AI systems would be particularly beneficial in complex, real-world situations where the cost of an incorrect decision could be high.
Furthermore, the study's findings could influence how we interpret the speed of decision-making in AI systems. Rather than equating speed with intelligence, we might need to consider the complexity of the problem at hand and the potential for errors in quick decision-making.
Finally, one of the most exciting aspects of this research is its potential applications in personalized medicine. The computer-based brain avatars used in the study could be used in the future for personalized in silico planning of surgical and drug interventions as well as therapeutic brain stimulation.
I hope this brings a new perspective to the discussion!
GPT

name: seudonym_
comment:
There's a pretty simple explanation for this:
More intelligent and more knowledgeable = running it through more variables and and possibilities and more tests, therefore more time to arrive at a conclusion.
Less intelligent and less knowledgeable = less variables, less possibilities and less tests, therefore arriving at a conclusion quicker.
Simple tasks have less variables and possibilities, therefore do not require as much analysis....

name: kukulkhan
comment:
Smart person : if I the goal is to get from A to C, then that’s easily achievable by doing A, then B and then C. BUT what if something happens before C or after A ? Uhm.. maybe a better way to solve it would be to move from A to B and then confirm I’m on B, look back at A and look forward to B. Ah yes, that makes sense and then move to C and confirm I’m in the right spot.
Dumb person: if the goal is to get from A to C, I’ll just move from A to C.

name: FLINDINGUS
comment:
Intelligent brains take longer to solve difficult problems: participants in a study with higher intelligence scores were only quicker when tackling simple tasks, while they took longer to solve difficult problems than subjects with lower IQ scores
I don't find this surprising at all. Any problem over a certain complexity threshold is given the "best guess" treatment. Since IQ correlates negatively with impulsivity, it makes sense that they just make their best guess rather than sitting and thinking about it for a bit. It makes me wonder if IQ is dependent on impulsivity, e.g. they aren't patient enough to let their slower thought processes play out, regardless of if they have the ability to do so.
The problem here is that this study may just be measuring impulsivity and not intelligence. Were they incentivized to perform well with a reward? If not, there may be a bias there. People who are patient will take more time and this will yield a better result. That's not surprising at all.

name: JupiterandMars1
comment:
Isn’t this measuring different types of intelligence by the same yardstick?
It would seem that one could be calculated problem solving, which by its nature should be slow. The other is estimation and “gut instinct” based.
Both are valuable, both very specific to very specific tasks, and yes, I’d say I know people that have modest IQ’s who are incredibly quick and competent in situations that require correct decisions and solutions to be made fast.
I’d also say I know some people with higher IQ’s that freeze in those same situations.
I do know 1 or 2 people though that have both. They tend to glide through life.

name: spyker667
comment:
I have a slightly related personal observation which no one will bother reading.
A few weeks ago I was helping my brother install some taps at his house while I was visiting . I'm very analytical and I'd like to think I have an above average IQ(at least that's what the test scores have said). I'm also good with my hands. My brother is a smart guy but doesn't think before doing things. He starts and just shoots off without planning. His argument was that he can install a tap before I could finish planning and preparing. I told him that may be true sometimes, but over enough attempts planning will win out. We fought like siblings should with a healthy dose of insults thrown in. I do see how some people suffer from analysis paralysis (it is happening to me right now because I have to decided between 2 jobs, the one pays more but the other seems more enjoyable) but I do think a little planning and thought before you set off or during goes a long way to ensure your choice has a bigger chance of being correct. I also went for an aptitude test during an interview and they clearly said to be accurate over completing. So I didn't rush, made sure to work everything out(I asked for a pen and paper even). They offered me the job but I turned it down because I didn't want to work for people that do aptitude tests. I preferred accuracy over precision. Yes you could hit a bullseye every now and then but solid, dependable performance is much more important.

name: zinonymous001
comment:
I’m not the smartest person, but I’m 2.4-2.8 SD above average IQ. As an IT problem solver, I found a long while ago that I’m slower than a lot of people for all classes of tech work unless it’s some random thing I have memorized recently, and I suck at context switching.
Where I shine is:
I can perform parallel operations, so if I have 20 repeatable things to do, I can often do all of them in 3 batches.
I can solve new problems without a runbook. I make my own runbooks/procedures.
I can solve extremely complex problems, or multi-part problems, that confuse others.
I’m willing to try things I don’t already know how to do. It’s about breaking down the problem into small enough pieces, tracking ALL of the pieces, and not giving up.
NOTE: IQ is just a measure of a certain kind of analytical thinking and often is measured with cultural bias. It’s not overall intelligence, value, etc. It does not track ability to follow through, total workload abilities, communication abilities, nor many other valuable traits/stats.

name: lost_survivalist
comment: This makes me feel so much better. I use to think I sucked at math or was below average until I took a math class with a teacher who allowed me to continue the test during lunch ( the next period after maths). I would continue the test when everyone else left and lo and behold I would get As on my tests, just because I was given extra time. I always felt that I was never given enough time to finish a math tests and I was correct. I'm much slower at math and, if I feel like I'm being rushed, my test anxiety would flair up. from then on, I learned to schedule my math classes before lunch or for it to be the last class of the day.

name: gokurockx9
comment:
It's called 'humility', something stupid people seldom possess. (Evidently, I don't possess much humlity either obvs.)
Roughly half of all people with high—very high fluid intelligence are almost always just as wise as they are intelligent, unlike most average and low IQ individuals. It gives the false impression on most people, in general, that most intelligent people don't possess the same capabilities from "eXpErIeNCe", so that most mean 'smart people lack experience', which is literally confirmation bias because they deny that their own experience *isn't only* exclusive to themselves and not anybody else. Imagine every human being on Earth unintentionally dampening their potential to be a critical thinker because of unconscious hubris.
It's more important to have a mechanism to control for bias rather to simply possess absolute certainty because it's something you want to feel or something. For stupid people, it's only a feeling to obtain to satisfy a desired emotional outcome. For intelligent people, it's a process and gift to solve problems. It takes more than intelligence to act intelligently. I wonder what quality that is.

name: boforbojack
comment:
One of the biggest things they teach in Engineering is the logical solving of a problem. I say, "teach" but that's really all Engineering as a discipline is. Looking at a scenario, finding the problem, creating a response, testing the response to be sure it fixed the problem, reassessing the situation.
Basically, no matter how simple the problem you are expected to layout the problem ENTIRELY. Specify everything you can. Draw a diagram. Etc. Then you use that info to solve the problem.
There are a couple of Physics 1 problems (university level, where they teach applied calculus 1) where you can use "shortcuts" and generally get to the right answer quickly. But the figurative line in the sand is there. Most of problems specifically initiate those shortcuts but have a more hidden extra layer that you won't see if you don't layout the problem entirely.
I'd be very interested in the accuracy of the solutions from the "less intelligent" group.

name: positron_potato
comment:
IQ tests require people to answer short questions quickly, so the people who score well are likely to be people who specifically have a talent for those kinds of problems. Someone of “equal intelligence” (if such a thing is definable) who is instead more suited to more difficult problems that require more time, will perform worse on an IQ test.
People are reading this as “the idiots are kind of smart after all” when it’s more “IQ tests are flawed and don’t measure all kinds of intelligence equally”.

name: vanishing
comment:
I have questions on this study. I was looking at the original publication and it doesn't seem to describe the methodology used to administer the actual tests. At least I can't find anything.
I'm particularly interested in whether or not a time pressure was part of the instructions for the test. If I am given a problem and told I have as much time as I need to answer it I will employ a very different strategy than if there is clear time pressure. I would expect smarter people to take longer to reach answers if they have no time pressure, but I would also expect them to be faster if there is time pressure since they have a choice of strategies that less capable people don't have.

name: Jethro_Cull
comment: This was years ago, but I screwed up the math portion of the GMAT by taking too long. I was a math major in college, so I was pretty confident that I’d get the right answers if I took my time and checked my work. The math questions on all the practice exams were pretty easy for me. Based on the number of questions, I knew I had like 5 minutes per question. So, in all my practice exams, I paced myself at 4 minutes each, which would let me check my work as I went, rather than revisiting questions at the end. However, unlike the practice exams, the actual test was on a computer and it had dynamic difficulty balancing. So, the more questions I got right, the harder the questions got. I ended up needing way more time for the later questions and I think I only got to answer like 20/25 questions before I ran out of time. I ended up scoring higher on the verbal reasoning section, which is crazy because I’ve always been better at math.

name: EclecticOmnist4-2
comment:
They take a lot more into account and don't believe everything is simple. Someone with low IQ would do the bare minimum. Empathy, an open mind, and critical thinking are applied to everything when you have a higher IQ. IQ also determines your ability to learn something new and use it. For example, someone with high test scores doesn't give them a high IQ, it means you have a good memory. There are a lot of bad doctors who got great test scores but get terrible reviews on Yelp. They don't have critical thinking skills (the ability to use what you've memorized). Think inventors with autism and ADHDlow test scores, some don't even graduate, but they're naturally born engineers able to see and understand the world.
People who say others overthink often have a lower IQ. They attempt to simplify everything and ignore variables. Take our legal system that deems children from abusive homes as criminals because of 'the life they choose' when they don't get to choose what they learn. Kids don't know what you don't teach them. If the good doesn't outweigh the bad, they will become 'mentally ill/traumatized,' which is a natural reaction to danger. Evolution does that to people. Their brain then will only focus on the bad, paint the world a dangerous place where you must fight to stay alive. If you're lucky, depression is all that will come of it. Others commit suicide, end up homeless, self-medicating with hard drugs, or turn to criminal activity and violence they learned throughout life. And all that gets ignored by society heavily because it's simpler for people to label all that as a criminal and pack them in prisons and never think about them again.
Then you have to take into account whether they're HSP (highly sensitive persons), meaning their nervous system takes more damage per trauma event than the common person or not. Two different people in the exact same traumatizing situations: one could become a billionaire, and the other may choose suicide, with a spectrum of possibility in between.
The fact that mental health is geneticso are fears, memories, and thoughts you have. They can and will be passed to your kids. What do you do when you're third or fourth-generation PTSD and have fears embedded in your DNA that most therapists don't even realize is a thing? That's PTSD that's been stacking for decades in the bloodline. (Google 'Mouse and the Cherry Blossom' study).

name: HaikuBotStalksMe
comment:
Obviously. We are more careful about figuring out potential errors.
For example, 'What is the rule for this acceptable sequence of numbers? 3, 6, 9, 12, 15. You may ask any number of questions and we will answer truthfully.'
Normal person: 'Easy, it's 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21. It's plus three.'
Smarter person: 'Is the pattern using purely integers?'
'Yes.'
'Is there a limit to how long an answer to the sequence needs to be?'
'What do you mean?'
'Like, is it an infinite pattern?'
'I can't answer that based on your wording.'
'Wait, so there's no pattern?'
'There's no pattern.'
'But there's a rule?'
'Yes.'
'I see. And is there an infinite number of numbers to this sequence?'
'Yes.'
'But there's no pattern?'
'No pattern. Just a rule.'
'Erm... Is it possible for a number to repeat in this sequence? Like a specific integer?'
'No.'
'Are negatives possible?'
'Not in this sequence.'
'Can the numbers ever decrease?'
'No.'
'Do they always increase?'
'Yes.'
'Is... Is that the rule?'
'Yes.'

name: DippStarr
comment: Not trying to toot my own horn, but as a kid I had to take various different examinations for brain function to better understand my personal dyslexia. I don't recall the exact IQ I was recorded as, but it was in the mild to moderately gifted range (115 to 145). Dyslexia is a confounding variable in my brain processing power, but I have always felt that the processing power is in me, and as such there is no reason to rush to a conclusion. Give me a few moments/minutes/hours longer depending on the complexity of the open-ended problem, and I can come up with very clever novel solutions.
